summary: astroviruses form a family of small, non-enveloped, positive strand RNA viruses that infect many animals. first identified in human stool samples in 1975, these viruses were named after their star-shaped appearance in some electron micrographs. astroviruses have been shown to replicate in cells of the intestinal tracts of infected organisms. a domestic rabbit colony of about 100 animals experienced an outbreak of enterocolitis near Johnson City, TN, USA. the predominant rabbit breeds were angora, satin and mini rex. no changes in diet had occurred in 1.5 years. 4 of 5 small intestinal cultures grew E. coli that was found not to be an attaching effacing effacing E. coli. electron microscopy observed 30 nm virus-like particles in the stool of 1 of 2 animals tested. initial attempts to isolate virus from 2 samples in tissue culture were unsuccessful. virus-like particles were observed but diagnostic testing failed to identify known viruses. several samples were subjected to Virochip analysis. total nucleic acid was extracted from the stool of four sick animals and one unaffected control. additional degenerate primers and 3′ RACE were used to recover a 5 kbp contiguous sequence. but repeated attempts using 5′ RACE and other PCR-based strategies failed to recover the full predicted 7 kb genome. the average Sanger quality score of these sequences was 19.5 at base 1, 17.3 at base 100, and 14.4 at base 150. the average Sanger quality score of these sequences was 19.5 at base 1, 17.3 at base 100, and 14.4 at base 150. deletions occurred at a frequency of 1.3% (1.3 indels per 100 bases aligned), more frequent than mismatches, which occurred at a frequency of 0.28%. 1.9105 unique sequences (6% of sequences) derived from the astrovirus, corresponding to >1000x average coverage of its genome. mmalian cell lines previously shown to support the replication of human astroviruses: Vero, HT-29, and Caco-2. culture supernatants were collected on days 1, 2, 4, 6, 10 and 15 post innoculation. rabbit astrovirus RNA was detected in the day 1 supernatant (in the innoculum) Phylogeny based on the first 420 amino acids of the indicated ORF2 (capsid) sequences. RT-PCR using these primers indicated that only the EM-positive sick rabbit tested positive for the virus. nm virus-like particles were observed in the stool of 1 of 2 animals tested. PCR-based testing determined that this virus was not Rabbit Hemorrhagic Disease Virus. intestinal Eimeria spp. E. coli ND ND ND ND Trichuris spp. 8 (Control) – ND ND ND ND () EM VLPs, virus-like particles evident by electron microscopic examination. ND, not determined. coli, Escherichia coli, Clostridium perfringens. overlapping PCR, 5′, and 3′ RACE amplicons used to determine and confirm the sequence of the viral genome. the average pairwise percent identity between the predicted rabbit astrovirus protein sequences and the sequences of the proteins from the astroviruses shown in Figure 3. astrovirus diagnostic ATAATAACATGGTCAACTATTGGCTTC MDS-120 Rabbit astrovirus diagnostic GACATCCTTATACATTTTCACAACTTT MDS-156 Vertebrate rRNA (L2513) GCCTGTTTACCAAAAACATCAC MDS-157 Vertebrate rRNA (H2714) CTCCATAGGGTCTT MDS-298 Genome recovery and sequencing (27–46 forward) TCTGGTTTGT MDS-150 Genome recovery and sequencing (5759–5779 reverse) TCTGAAATTGCACTGTGTGTTGG MDS-121 RACE oligo-dT primer CCAGTGAGCAGAGCT17 MDS-122 RACE outer adapter primer GAGGACTCGAGCTCAAGC. the average Sanger quality score of these sequences was 19.5 at base 1, 17.3 at base 100, and 14.4 at base 150. 56 sequences aligned best to Eimeria species, consistent with the clinical diagnosis of coccidiosis. a small percentage (0.4%) of human sequences were also evident in the data. library contamination was also the likely source of 27 reads with nucleotide sequences nearly identical to human immunodeficiency virus-1. rabbit virus nsp1A, nsp1B, and capsid proteins share 30%, 59%, and 25% pairwise amino acid identity with the corresponding Astrovirus MLB1 protein sequences. the rabbit virus capsid sequence does not form a well-supported clade with the astrovirus MLB1 capsid sequences, but branches along the lineage leading to the canonical human astroviruses. the virus was isolated from the feces of a rabbit suffering from enterocolitis. it is not clear that the virus caused the disease in this instance. astroviruses cause gastroenteritis in other mammals. the rabbit astrovirus genome contains characteristics typical of astrovirus genomes. it is likely that ORF1A can be translated by itself or in conjunction with ORF1B via a conserved AAAAAAC motif. the nsp1A protein is predicted to contain several transmembrane and coiled coil domains. it is likely that the nsp1A contains other functional domains of as yet unknown function. the nsp1A protein is the most conserved of the three polyproteins. the protein exhibits a much lower degree of sequence similarity to other astrovirus proteins sequences. this is in agreement with the model that the N-terminal half of astrovirus capsid polyproteins form a conserved core domain and the C-terminal halves of the proteins are highly variable receptor interacting domains. the 87 nt predicted 3′ untranslated region is followed by a polyA tail. RNA was reverse transcribed in reactions containing 1x reaction buffer, 5 mM dithiothreitol, 1.25 mM dNTPs, 20 pmoles primer MDS-4 and 100 ng template. PCRs contained 1x reaction buffer, 2 M primer, 0.25 mM dNTPs, 2 U taq DNA polymerase, and 2 l library template. sec, 40°C for 30 sec, and 72°C for 1 min, then 25 cycles of 95°C for 30 sec, 58°C for 30 sec, and 72°C for 1 min, with a final extension of 72°C for 5 min. resulting amino-allyl-containing DNA was purified using a DNA Clean and Concentrator-5 column (DNA-CC-5; Zymo Research) cDNA was prepared in reverse transcription reactions containing 1x reaction buffer, 5 mM dithiothreitol, 1.25 mM dNTPs, 20 pmoles random hexamer primer, 100 U Superscript III (invitrogen) and 100 ng RNA template. cDNA was adapted for Ion Torrent sequencing using the Ion Xpress Library Kit (catalog # 4468987). RNA by RT-PCR was diluted 1:10 in PBS and filtered through a 0.22 m filter (Millipore) culture supernatant was harvested and replaced at the indicated time points. RNA was extracted from supernatant and reverse transcribed as described above. 380, HQ398856, HQ916313, HQ916314, HQ916316, HQ916317, JF414802, JF755422, L23513, NC_001943, NC_002469, NC_002470, NC_003790, NC_005790, NC_010646, NC_011400, NC_012437, NC_013060, NC_013443, NC_014320, the bowtie2 aligner was used to map unique reads to the Sanger-verified viral genome assembly. the number of gap openings (XO field) and mismatches (XM field) were tallied to the number of aligned bases in the bowtie2 SAM output. library preparation For virochip analysis, randomly-primed libraries were prepared from total nucleic acid. RNA was reverse transcribed in reactions containing 1x reaction buffer, 5 mM dithiothreitol, 1.25 mM dNTPs, 20 pmoles primer MDS-4, 100 U Superscript III (Invitrogen) and 100 ng template. the resulting amino-allyl-containing DNA was purified using a DNA Clean and Concentrator-5 column (DNA-CC-5; Zymo Research) the eluate was heat denatured at 95°C for 2 min, cooled briefly on ice, then fluorescently labeled in reactions containing 100 mM sodium bicarbonate pH 9, 10% DMSO. labeled DNA was added to hybridization reactions containing 3xSSC, 25 mM HEPES pH 7.4 and cDNA was prepared in reverse transcription reactions containing 1x reaction buffer, 5 mM dithiothreitol, 1.25 mM dNTPs, 20 pmoles random hexamer primer, 100 ng RNA template. cDNA was adapted for Ion Torrent sequencing using the Ion Xpress Library Kit (catalog # 4468987). culture supernatant was harvested and replaced at the indicated time points and stored at 80°C until processing. RNA was extracted from supernatant and reverse transcribed as described above. sequences were aligned using Clustal (version 2.0.12) using default parameters. alignment is based on the first 420 amino acids of the protein sequences. sequence of the rabbit astrovirus has been deposited in GenBank. the number of gap openings (XO field) and mismatches (XM field) were tallied to determine the frequency of indels and mismatches. the total number of aligned bases in the bowtie2 SAM output was determined directly from the Ion Torrent FASTQ output. the authors declare no competing interests.
